evidence.dc:description: RNA seq data from NCBI gene indicates the TBR1 is highly expressed, and has restricted expression within the brain.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Global classification of the human proteins with regards to spatial expression patterns across organs and tissues is important for studies of human biology and disease. Here, we used a quantitative transcriptomics analysis (RNA-Seq) to classify the tissue-specific expression of genes across a representative set of all major human organs and tissues and combined this analysis with antibody-based profiling of the same tissues. To present the data, we launch a new version of the Human Protein Atlas that integrates RNA and protein expression data corresponding to ∼80% of the human protein-coding genes with access to the primary data for both the RNA and the protein analysis on an individual gene level. We present a classification of all human protein-coding genes with regards to tissue-specificity and spatial expression pattern. The integrative human expression map can be used as a starting point to explore the molecular constituents of the human body.
dc:source.dc:creator: Fagerberg L
dc:source.dc:title: Analysis of the human tissue-specific expression by genome-wide integration of transcriptomics and antibody-based proteomics.

evidence.rdfs:label: TBR1 expression is restricted to the brain

evidence.dc:description:
BRET assay evaluated the interaction between TBR1 and the three brain-expressed isoforms of FOXP2 (Figure 6). FOXP2 Isoform one (cannonical) and isoform III (lacks the first 92 amino acids of isoform I), both nuclear localizinf isoforms, were able to interact with TBR1 (Figure 6B). Isoform 10+, a cytoplasmically localized FOXP2 isoform lacking the c-terminal region present in the cannonical isoform, was not able to interact with TBR1. This lack of interaction may indicate a critical region, or may be due to differences in localization.

These assay support initial findings from a yeast-2 hybrid assay that indicated the N-terminal region was important for the interaction of FOXP2 with TBR1 (PMID: 21653829).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Next-generation sequencing recently revealed that recurrent disruptive mutations in a few genes may account for 1% of sporadic autism cases. Coupling these novel genetic data to empirical assays of protein function can illuminate crucial molecular networks. Here we demonstrate the power of the approach, performing the first functional analyses of TBR1 variants identified in sporadic autism. De novo truncating and missense mutations disrupt multiple aspects of TBR1 function, including subcellular localization, interactions with co-regulators and transcriptional repression. Missense mutations inherited from unaffected parents did not disturb function in our assays. We show that TBR1 homodimerizes, that it interacts with FOXP2, a transcription factor implicated in speech/language disorders, and that this interaction is disrupted by pathogenic mutations affecting either protein. These findings support the hypothesis that de novo mutations in sporadic autism have severe functional consequences. Moreover, they uncover neurogenetic mechanisms that bridge different neurodevelopmental disorders involving language deficits.
dc:source.dc:creator: Deriziotis P
dc:source.dc:title: De novo TBR1 mutations in sporadic autism disrupt protein functions.

evidence.rdfs:label: TBR1 interacts with FOXP2

evidence.dc:description: This assay indicates the critical region of biding of FOXP2, and confirms prior evidence obtained from yeast 2 hybrid (Y2H) assays (PMID: 21653829), indicating a physical relationship between FOXP2 and TBR1, therefore the points have been increased.

Y2H assays revelawed that TBR1 interacts with CASK (Fugure 1). The interaction was resolved to indicate the critical region for interaction is the c-terminal domain of TBR1 (residues 342-681). Co-iimunoprecipitation assys in Cos-7 cells confirmed the interaction of the two proteins in vitro (Figure 1b-c). Furthermore, exogenous expression of Tbr1 and CASK in COS-7 cells followed by and immunohistochemistry indicated changes to localization consistent with interaction ( Figure 2).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Membrane-associated guanylate kinases (MAGUKs) contain multiple protein-binding domains that allow them to assemble specific multiprotein complexes in particular regions of the cell. CASK/LIN-2, a MAGUK required for EGF receptor localization and signalling in Caenorhabditis elegans, contains a calmodulin-dependent protein kinase-like domain followed by PDZ, SH3 and guanylate kinase-like domains. In adult rat brain, CASK is concentrated at neuronal synapses and binds to the cell-surface proteins neurexin and syndecan and the cytoplasmic proteins Mint/LIN-10 and Veli/LIN-7. Here we report that, through its guanylate kinase domain, CASK interacts with Tbr-1, a T-box transcription factor that is involved in forebrain development. CASK enters the nucleus and binds to a specific DNA sequence (the T-element) in a complex with Tbr-1. CASK acts as a coactivator of Tbr-1 to induce transcription of T-element containing genes, including reelin, a gene that is essential for cerebrocortical development. Our findings show that a MAGUK which is usually associated with cell junctions has a transcription regulation function.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hsueh YP
dc:source.dc:title: Nuclear translocation and transcription regulation by the membrane-associated guanylate kinase CASK/LIN-2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Tbr1 interacts with CASK

evidence.dc:description: Given the extensive experimentation to confirm the interaction and multiple assays, the points have been increased.
CASK is also a known T-box binding transcription factor that is implicated in complex neurodevelopmental disorders
evidence.rdfs:label: TBR1 is a T-box transcription factor like CASK

evidence.dc:description: Given the overlapping functions of TBR1 and CASK for not only being transcription factors but being in the same T-box binding family and regulating neuronal development, the score has been increased.

The CD-1 Tbr1 homozygous null mice were able to survive to at least postnatal day 14 days (whereas Tbr1 homozygous null mice on the C57/bl6 background are embryonic lethal). P14 mouse brain indicated changes to brain structure consistent with cortical malformations (Figure 4), including alterations to the cortical layers. They also observed severe thinning indicating postnatal growth defects, atrophy or apoptosis of cells.

The original Tbr2 mutant mice on the C57/Bl6 mice were analyzed for behavioral abnormalities in Huang et al., 2014 (PMID: 24441682). According to this article the heterozygous Tbr1 (+/-) mice showed deficits in learning and memory using the conditioned taste aversion assay (Figure 5A, PMID: 24441682) and auditory fear conditioning (Figure 5b, PMID: 24441682). the Tbr1 +/- mice did not recognize sucrose as a hazard after LiCl treatment indicating learning impairment. For the auditory fear conditioning the Tbr1+/- mice showed a lower freezing response compared to wildtype littermates. No change in behavior were observed in the Tbr1+/- mice compared to wildtypes in the open-field, elevated plus maze, novel object recognition, or contextual fear.

Thee mice have been studied and reference in 17 papers according to MGI: http://www.informatics.jax.org/reference/allele/MGI:2179766?typeFilter=Literature

dc:source.dc:abstract: TBR1, a T-box transcription factor expressed in the cerebral cortex, regulates the expression of several candidate genes for autism spectrum disorders (ASD). Although TBR1 has been reported as a high-confidence risk gene for ASD and intellectual disability (ID) in functional and clinical reports since 2011, TBR1 has only recently been recorded as a human disease gene in the OMIM database. Currently, the neurodevelopmental disorders and structural brain anomalies associated with TBR1 variants are not well characterized. Through international data sharing, we collected data from 25 unreported individuals and compared them with data from the literature. We evaluated structural brain anomalies in seven individuals by analysis of MRI images, and compared these with anomalies observed in TBR1 mutant mice. The phenotype included ID in all individuals, associated to autistic traits in 76% of them. No recognizable facial phenotype could be identified. MRI analysis revealed a reduction of the anterior commissure and suggested new features including dysplastic hippocampus and subtle neocortical dysgenesis. This report supports the role of TBR1 in ID associated with autistic traits and suggests new structural brain malformations in humans. We hope this work will help geneticists to interpret TBR1 variants and diagnose ASD probands.
dc:source.dc:creator: Nambot S
dc:source.dc:title: De novo TBR1 variants cause a neurocognitive phenotype with ID and autistic traits: report of 25 new individuals and review of the literature.

evidence.detectionMethod: Used MIP technology to sequence genes of interest. For de novo mutations confirmation of the de novo status was confirmed by Sanger sequencing of the proband that the parents for the variant of interest. No other genetic variations were noted for this individual.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Primary diagnosis noted as autism spectrum disorder (Supplementary Table 1), however cognitive function noted as average range. Verbal IQ scored 98, non-verbal IQ scored 81. Noted as being verbally fluent, and possible language regression.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband was part of the Simons Simplex Complex cohort and may have had some sequencing not indicated in this paper.
evidence.rdfs:label: 13060.p1

evidence.dc:description: The p.P542RR variant lies within a the CASK binding region of TBR1, 3’ to the T-box. This variant was inherited from the the probands father. Immunocytochemistry of transiently transfected HEK293 cells shows normal localization to the nucleus, similar to wildtype TBR1 (Figure 2C). Also the p.Q418RE variant showed no altered functional capability compared to wildtype for the following: transcriptional repression (Figure 3), homodimerization (figure 5), or colocalization and interaction with CASK and FOXP2. This variant is not present in gnomAD. Given the lack of variant evidence to support abnormal function compared to wildtype, the score has been reduced from default.

The proband was noted to have a rare CNV duplication that was inherited from the father on chromosome 6 (Chr6: 26,077,937-26,375,779 dup inherited from the father.) according to O'Roak et al 2012 (PMID: 23160955) Supplementary table 16. Furthermore they were indicated to have rare mutations in the other following genes IRF2BPL (missense) and SLC40A1 (synonomous) Table S18 of O'Roak 2012 (PMID: 23160955). Also noted in Satterstrom et al 2019 in biorXiv to have two variants in the gene AHNAK2, supplementary table 2, link: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/484113v3.supplementary-material

evidence.rdfs:label: 11480.p1

evidence.dc:description: This variant produces a truncated protein that is missing the T-box transcriptional domain. Immunocytochemistry of transiently transfected HEK293 cells expressing the p.A136PfsX80 variant shows perturbed localization, as the variant protein no longer localizes to the nucleus (Figure 2C). the p.A136PfsX80 also shows an inability to repress transcprition in luciferase assays compared to wildtype TBR1 (Figure 3). BRET analysis indicates that the TBR1 p.A136Pfsx80 variant is unable to bind FOXP2 (Figure 6). Of note, the proband was also indicated to have a paternally inherited CNV on Chromosome 6, and de novo variant in three other genes (IRF2BPL (missense) and SLC40A1 (synonomous), AHNAK2 (missense, synonomous)). Given the multiple genes that have been identified over several different studies, it is unclear also of the mechanism of function for TBR1 in the disease, the score have been decreased from default. This individual has been previously published in the following articles PMID: 23160955 (O'Roak 2012) same group, PMID: 25284784 (Dong et al., 2014), PMID: 25363768 (Iossofov et al., 2014).

evidence.rdfs:label: 13796.p1,

evidence.dc:description: The p.S351X produces a premature stop codon that deletes the last part of the T-box along with the entire 3’ end of TBR1. Immunocytochemistry of transiently transfected HEK293 cells shows mislocalization of the p. S351X variant within the cytoplasm and within aggregates in the nucleus (Figure 2C). BRET analysis indicates that the p.S351X variant lacks the ability to homodimerize to wildtype TBR1, indicating perturbed or abnormal function (Figure 5A). Other pertubations noted include the inability to repress transcription, an colocalize with CASK and FOXP2. Of note, the proband was noted to have a large duplication iherited from the mother present on chromosome 6, and a de novo mutation in the gene FAM92B. While there is variant evidene to support an abnormal function, there are indications that other variation may contribute, therefore the score was reduced from default. Proband was previously published in PMID: 23160955 (O'Roak 2012.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (70th centile), length (-2.5 SD), OFC (-2 SD). Growth parameters at 11 years old, weight (90th centile), length (+2 SD), OFC (-1 SD). No developmental milestones noted. Brain MRI indicated thick anterior corpus callosum, age of evalutation unknown.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 24

evidence.dc:description: This variant is located in the last exon and is not expected to go through NMD. There is no functional evidence to support the pathogenicity, therefore the points have been reduced from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: TRIO-exome as reported in Neale et al., 2012 (PMID: 22495311). De novo status was confirmed by either Sanger sequencing or by Sequenom MALDI-TOF genotyping of the prband and parents for the genes of interest. Of note, the patient was also found to have a de novo mutation in FGF22 (c.250G>A, p.V84M), which has a maximum MAF reported in gnomAD of 2.527E-4 in East Asian population (present in 5 individuals), and overall found in 16 individuals in heterozygous cases. Link: https://gnomad.broadinstitute.org/variant/19-643270-G-A?dataset=gnomad_r2_1 Satterstrom et al, 2019 on BioRxiv indicate that the proband also harbors a variant in the gene TTN, supplementary table 2: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/484113v3.supplementary-material.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Proband was initially noted in Neale 2012 as autism spectrum disorder. Full IQ score was noted as 69, with verbal IG noted as 69 and nonverbal IG of 74. Met requirement for austim according to ADI-R (Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised).
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband noted as having no previous family history of autism.
evidence.rdfs:label: Neale 2012- 09C86232A

evidence.dc:description: Functional assays of transiently transfected HEK293 cells performed in this paper show that the N374H variant still localizes to the nucleus, like wildtype TBR1, however it tends to form aggregates (Figure 2C). Also, this variant has the same amount of transcriptional repression as wildtype (Figure 3). Furthermore, the N347H variant still has the ability to homodimerize with itself, like wildtype TBR1, however the ability to interact with CASK and FOXP2 was reduced or abolished (Figure 6). Additional studies from Huang et al, 2014 (PMID: 24441682), also showed expression of the N374H TBR2 variant in heterozygous TBR1 knockout amygdalar neurons showed a failure to rescue axon outgrowth like wildtype TBR1, indicating the variation affected function. Given the varying variant evidence to support pathogenicity and the general lack of knowledge of the molecular mechanism of TBR1 that are contributing disease, the points have been decreased from default. Case previously reported as 22495311 (Neale et al., 2012, Supplementary Table) same patient number.

evidence.detectionMethod: Single Exome sequencing. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters notes as decreased weight (5th centile), decreased length (-2.5SD), microcephaly (PFC= -2 SD). At 10 years of age OFC still measured -2 SD, while weight increased (-2 SD) and length was ~ normal (-0.5 SD). Walking age noted as 3 years. Bulimia noted to begin at age 4 years. Indicate body balancing. Brain MRI at 16 years old indicated ventricular dilatation, cyst of the cavum vergae. EEG indicated right temporal spikes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 3

evidence.dc:description: This variant is non-LOF variant, there is no variant evidence, and no previous testing indicated so the score has been reduced from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Gene Panel (Either HaloPlex or SureSelect QXT) including 456 genes implicated in ID/ASD, NGS performed using MiSeq. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (25th centile), length (-1.5 SD), OFC (median). Growth parameters at 7.75 years old, weight (50th centile), length (+1.75 SD), OFC (+1.6 SD). Developmental milestones noted as sitting (10 months), walking (18 months). Autistic features measured by DSM IV and/or ADOS, also noted as having selective eating disorder. Reduced reflexes noted. Brain MRI at 2.5 years indicated as normal. EEG indicated an asymmetric slow pattern without paroxysmal activity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 14

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio Exome sequencing. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (3rd centile), length (median), OFC (< -3 SD). Growth parameters at 3 years old, weight (60th centile), length (+1 SD, OFC (-2 SD). Developmental milestones noted as sitting (NA), walking (21 months). The dermoid cysts was indicated as T12-L3 vertebrae level.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 10

evidence.dc:description: This is a synonymous variant with no functional evidence to support the pathogenicity, therefore point were reduced from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio Exome sequencing. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (10th centile), length (NA), OFC (NA). Growth parameters at 5.75 years old, weight (60th centile), length (NA), OFC (-2 SD). Developmental milestones noted as sitting (11-12 months), walking (21 months). Noted as having rigid thinking and imitative behavior. Seizures noted as refractory with sensitivity to geometric patterns and light. BRain MRI at 2 years old indicated as normal. EEG indicates superimposed paroxysms of higher frequency, generalized spike wave in parieto-temporal region.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 11

evidence.dc:description: This variant is non-LOF variant, there is no variant evidence, and no previous testing indicated so the score has been reduced from default.

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio Exome sequencing. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (20th centile), length (NA), OFC (NA). Growth parameters at 21 years old, weight (<3rd centile), length (-2 SD), OFC (-3 SD). Developmental milestones noted as sitting (NA), walking (unable to walk). Noted to have gripping. Brain MRI at 16 years old indicated ventriculomegaly, frontal cortical dysplasia, thin AC, dysplastic hippocampi. EEG at 18 years old indicated left temporal sharp and spike waves, diffuse arrhythmic slowdown.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 20

evidence.dc:description: This variant is located in the last exon and is not expected to go through NMD. It has also been reported in 6, seemingly unrelated individuals in Nambot et al, 2020 (PMID: 32005960) as well as at least 3 other papers (Vegas et al., 2018; PMID: 30268909; Gilissen et al, 2014, PMID:24896178; Neale et al., 2012 PMID: 22495311).

evidence.detectionMethod: Single Exome sequencing. All SNVs were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was also performed by Sanger sequencing to confirm either segregation or de novo status.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth parameters: weight (50th centile), length (-0.5 SD), OFC (NA). Growth parameters at 6 years old, weight (75th centile), length (+1.3 SD), OFC (-3 SD). Developmental milestones noted as sitting (8 months), walking (aid required). Autistic features were noted as DSM IV and/or ADPS. Noted to be ritualistic and having sensory disorder. Brain MRI at 2 years old indicated normal.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case: 22

evidence.dc:description: This variant is located in the last exon and is not expected to go through NMD. No functional evidence to support the pathogenicity, therefore the score was reduced.

evidence.detectionMethod: Used MIP technology to sequence genes of interest. For de novo mutations confirmation of the de novo status was confirmed by Sanger sequencing of the proband that the parents for the variant of interest. No other genetic variations were noted for this individual.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Primary diagnosis noted as autism spectrum disorder (Supplementary Table 1), as well as developmental coordination disorder. Verbal IQ scored 75, non-verbal IQ scored 78. Noted as being verbally fluent, and having "elevated externalizing symptoms."
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband was part of the Simons Simplex Complex cohort and may have had some sequencing not indicated in this paper.
evidence.rdfs:label: 13814.p1

evidence.dc:description: The p.K228E variant occurs within the T-box transcriptional domain of TBR1. Immunocytochemistry of transiently transfected HEK293 cells shows normal localization to the nucleus, however formation of aggregates is noted (Figure 2C). No changes to transcriptional repression activity were noted compared to wildtype TBR1, indicating retained function. BRET analysis indicates that the p.K228E variant retains the normal ability to homodimerize to wildtype TBR1 (Figure 5A), however analysis with FOXP2 shows reduced or abolished ability to interact (Figure 6). Furthermore, an animal model overexpressing this variant suggests a gain of function mechanism due to increased expression of the variant. Given that the variant evidence suggests little to no perturbation to wildtype TBR1 transcriptional activity, the score has been decreased from default.

dc:description:
Variation in TBR1 was first reported in individuals in relation to autism spectrum disorder in 2014 by Deriziotis et al. (PMID: 25232744). TBR1 has also been associated with intellectual developmental disorder with autism and speech delay (OMIM #606053), 2q24 microdeletion syndrome, occipital pachygyria and polymicrogyria. Since then, phenotypes associated with variants in TBR1 have been expanded and range from autism spectrum disorder, delayed speech and language development, joint hypermobility, severe intellectual disability/global developmental delay, abnormality of the skull, cerebral palsy, etc. (Deriziotis et al., 2014 PMID: 25232744; Huang et al., 2014 PMID: 24441682; Palumbo et al., 2014 PMID:24458984).Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, the ID/Autism GCEP decided to lump into one disease entity, complex neurodevelopmental disorder (Mondo:0100038). There are individuals that have been reported with other phenotypes including joint hypermobility and muscle dysfunction. It is unclear at this time whether these phenotypes are related to variants in TBR1 or are due to other circumstances. Most proband information was collected from large case control studies where other phenotypic features are not reported, therefore making the phenotypic profile unclear.

Twenty-six variants (missense, in-frame indel, frameshift) have been included in this curation. These variants have been reported in thirty-two individuals across two publications (PMIDs: 25232744, 32005960).More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be LOF. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by protein interactions, expression studies, animal models, and biochemical function studies (PMIDs: 25232744, 24309898, 10749215, 32005960). In summary, TBR1 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This curation was approved by the ID/Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on 03/25/2020.
